thread.title: Carmody was my biggest regret: Newman
thread.title_full: Carmody was my biggest regret: Newman | Business Spectator

author: AAP
title: Carmody was my biggest regret: Newman
text:
The controversial appointment of Tim Carmody as Queensland's chief justice is the decision Campbell Newman most regrets during his 13-year political career.
The former premier and Brisbane Lord Mayor has opened up about his time in politics in an authorised biography, Can Do: Campbell Newman and the Challenge of Reform, penned by former Liberal National Party MP Gavin King.
The book covers much of Mr Newman's early life and political career, with a particular focus on how "the LNP lost the unlosable election" in January when Annastacia Palaszczuk lead Labor to an unlikely victory.
Mr Newman singled out Mr Carmody's appointment as his biggest regret, given the chief justice resigned in July this year without achieving the reform Mr Newman thought the courts badly needed.
"I'm upset on a personal level because we've got egg all over our faces," Mr Newman said of Mr Carmody's short tenure.
"I'm upset that one of the most public and high-level examples of bullying this country has ever seen has happened and the bullies have won."
The book took particular aim at Queensland Court of Appeal President Margaret McMurdo, describing her as a vocal part of the "judicial elite" who saw Mr Carmody's humble upbringing as a "former public housing kid" as foreign, making him an outsider.
It's not the only claim of bullying, with the book dedicating large sections to the behaviour of the media - in particular parliamentary press gallery reporters - and their influence on the 2015 election result.
Mr Newman said the media were more interested in the "politics of politics" than scrutinising policies.
"Since when was it right or acceptable for reporters (to) set up camp outside the house where the Premier of the state lives, or the Attorney-General's house?" Mr Newman said.
"Why is it OK for reporters to chase and follow the Chief Justice through the Queen Street Mall?
"Grow up. Stop it."
The book also described a moment after a press conference in Cairns when Mr Newman realised he would lose his inner-Brisbane seat of Ashgrove, admitting to then-Barron River MP Michael Trout he was relieved because: "That's the last time I'll ever have to talk to that pack of bastards".
He also criticised the dirty campaign tactics of Labor and the unions against the LNP, singling out Deputy Premier Jackie Trad while she was working on the 2012 campaign before she became an MP.
Mr Newman, through Mr King, suggested the LNP would have won the 2015 election if it did more negative campaigning like Labor did.
The book also reveals a plan for Mr Newman to run for the LNP leadership in 2011 was kept from his wife Lisa for weeks and he only told her on the day speculation was due to appear in the news.
The secrecy sparked months of bitterness between the pair.
The book was initially supposed to be released next week but Dymocks in Brisbane's CBD began selling it on Friday, insisting it wasn't aware of an embargo.
